question.title: Calling Java from C using FFM
question.body:
I've recently come across FFM as an alternative to JNI for Java-to-C communication. However, I'm struggling with it.

Calling C from Java seems straightforward (downcalling). However, calling Java from C (upcalling) does not. The only example I can find involves having the Java call the C passing a Java method.

I was wondering if it is possible to have a C application call a Java method using FFM without the Java having passed something to the C application first, or is that only possible using JNI?

Thanks,

Carl

question_comments.body: JEP 472 doesn't mention or imply any plans to deprecate JNI, nor does it discourage using native code from Java when needed.

@Slaw I'm also confident it will never be deprecated. Go read JEP 472: "any interaction at all between Java code and native code is risky because it can compromise the integrity of applications and of the Java Platform itself." Bollocks. If JNI is so risky, why does java -verbose:jni -version require Java itself to make about 100 JNI calls? "OH NOES!!! C CODE IS SKEEERY!!!" is childish. Especially for a 35-year old feature. Language zealotry is tiresome. Benchmark OpenSSL vas "pure Java" Bouncy Castle. Java is S-L-O-W.

Regardless, I'm not sure what your doomsaying has to do with choosing JNI vs FFM. The existence of FFM is not a bad thing nor does it break anything using JNI. Choose the best tool for the job (including even if that means using a different language than Java).

I'm confident JNI will never be removed. I'm also confident it will never be deprecated. But I suppose there's a chance it may become obsolete for new projects in favor of FFM. That time is not now or even near, however, since JNI provides functionality that FFM doesn't and I know of no plans to change that. And yeah, Java has been moving towards strong encapsulation and "integrity" by default. Luckily, widely-used internal APIs like Unsafe--which projects used at they're own risk--are getting public, supported replacements. Seems like a good thing for long-term stability.

@Slaw Not yet, anyway If the Good Idea Fairies do manage to drop decades-old JNI they'll be writing the death warrant for Java. No enterprise will ever use Java for new development again if the language stewards decide to flush backwards compatibility down the toilet like that. Java will wind up as COBOL Jr. Or maybe the 2030's version of Pascal: an old language used to teach students who never use it again. It's no coincidence that Java fell from the #1 most-used language in 2015 to about 7th or 8th in the decade since the Java 9 rearchitecture debacle - big shops can't trust it.
"I was wondering if it is possible to have a C application call a Java method using FFM without the Java having passed something to the C application first." No.

@AndrewHenle FFM is not intended to outright replace JNI. Not yet, anyway; there may be future plans to make the two APIs fully interchangeable, but I'm not aware of any. FFM simply makes it possible to interact with native libraries which don't use JNI without having to write your own JNI native code. But if one needs the capabilities of JNI then they should use JNI.
